level.title: Getting Started - Basic Navigation
level.description: Learn the fundamental commands to navigate the Linux file system

exercises.title: Where Am I?
exercises.description: Use the 'pwd' command to print your current working directory. This command stands for 'print working directory' and shows you where you are in the file system.
hints: The command is just three letters: pwd

exercises.title: List Files
exercises.description: Use the 'ls' command to list files and directories in your current location.
hints: The command is just two letters: ls

exercises.title: Change Directory
exercises.description: Use the 'cd' command to change to the documents directory. Type: cd documents
hints: Don't forget to include the directory name after cd

exercises.title: Go Back Up
exercises.description: Use 'cd ..' to go back to the parent directory. The two dots (..) represent the parent directory.
hints: Don't forget the space between cd and ..

exercises.title: List Hidden Files
exercises.description: Use 'ls -a' to list all files, including hidden ones. Hidden files in Linux start with a dot (.).
hints: Flags modify how a command works
